title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Sharing Code
How do you share code?


R scripts and R Markdown/Quarto documents
RStudio Projects
GitHub Repository
R Package

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
section: When To Create an R Package?
text:
When To Create an R Package?

If you have certain recurring operations that occur across multiple projects.
Want to share data and documentation and not worry about file paths, file types, the documentation getting lost‚Ä¶
BUT, you will still use an RStudio Project (with a corresponding GitHub repo) for the code and data that are specific to a given project.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
R Packages

‚ÄúR packages are the fundamental unit of R-ness‚Äù. ‚Äì Jenny Bryan


Contains functions, (possibly) datasets, documentation, and tests.
‚Äúbase R‚Äù: 14 base packages that are preloaded

There are 15 other packages that also come preloaded.

CRAN has > 19,000 more packages

install.packages("dplyr")
library(dplyr)

And then there are all the packages on GitHub:

pak::pak("tidyverse/dplyr")
library(dplyr)

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
R Data Packages

Great way to share data!
Example 1:

library(mosaicData)
data(package = "mosaicData")
?Births2015

Example 2:

library(pdxTrees)
get_pdxTrees_parks()
get_pdxTrees_streets()

Example 3:

library(palmerpenguins)

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
R Packages
Why create an R package?

Very portable.
Includes documentation.
Provides a useful structure for organizing your work:

R folder: Code
tests folder: Testing functions
data folder: Storing data

Lots of helper functions in other packages to automate parts of the process.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Creating an R Package
Key packages:

devtools: supports the development and dissemination of the package
usethis: automates steps of package creation, such as constructing the data file
roxygen2: simplifies writing documentation

THE Book: R Packages, 2nd Edition

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Let‚Äôs Create an R Package!
Will focus on dog names in Cambridge, MA because I couldn‚Äôt find a corresponding PA version of this data‚Ä¶

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Our Package: camDogs
Goals:

Share the Dogs of Cambridge dataset, along with documentation.
Create a function that outputs a dataset of the dogs with the 10 most common names.
Useful MVP code:


library(tidyverse)
camDogs <- read_csv("https://data.cambridgema.gov/api/views/sckh-3xyx/rows.csv?accessType=DOWNLOAD")

camDogs <- mutate(camDogs,
               Breed = if_else(Dog_Breed == "Mixed Breed",
                               "Mixed", "Single"))

top10 <- function(data, x){

  # Find the 10 top based on x
  top10x <- count(data, {{x}}) %>%
    slice_max(n = 10, order_by = n) %>%
    select({{x}}) %>%
    pull()

   # Filter dataset to only the 10 top based on x
  return(filter(data, {{x}} %in% top10x))
}

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Example: Visualizing COVID Prevalence
In May of 2020, the Georgia Department of Public Health posted the following graph:






At a quick first glance, what story does the Georgia Department of Public Health graph appear to be telling?
What is misleading about the Georgia Department of Public Health graph? How could we fix this issue?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Example: Visualizing COVID Prevalence
After public outcry, the Georgia Department of Public Health said they made a mistake and posted the following updated graph:






How do your conclusions about COVID-19 cases in Georgia change when now interpreting this new graph?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Example: Visualizing COVID Prevalence
Alberto Cairo, a journalist and designer, created the second graph of the Georgia COVID-19 data:

 


A key principle of data visualization is to ‚Äúhelp the viewer make meaningful comparisons‚Äù.
What comparisons are made easy by the lefthand graph? What about by the righthand graph?
From these graphs, can we get an accurate estimate of the COVID prevalence in these Georgian counties over this two week period?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Example: Visualizing COVID Prevalence

The Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA) graph tracks the presence of COVID-19 in the Boston-area wastewater.











What are the pros of using wastewater over nasal swabs to assess COVID prevalence? What are the cons?
The graph also incorporates uncertainty measures. Quantifying uncertainty is a key component of data literacy.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Data Literacy In Action



Understanding the importance of context.



 Context explains the Monday jumps in the COVID counts.





How we encode information in a graph should be driven by our research question.



 You have a lot of design choices and these choices can help or hinder the story-telling.





How the data are collected impacts the conclusions we can draw.



 Voluntary COVID test results likely don‚Äôt provide good estimates of COVID prevalence.





Often we are using a sample of data to say something about a larger group. In this case, we should measure how certain our estimates are!



 They sampled the wastewater and then got a range of plausible values for the RNA copies each day.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Data Analysis Process




  

Need to understand how ‚Äúraw‚Äù data are processed into insights.
What choices were made at each step?
How do those choices impact the conclusions?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Data Literacy Training

About developing reasoning

Not just learning definitions and formulae
Not just memorizing arbitrary rules (p-value \(<\) 0.05, sample size \(>\) 30)

Requires judgment that takes time to develop

Lots of great classes at Bucknell where students practice!

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:

Workshops
Data Science Projects
Communities of Practice

rugB (R Users Group at Bucknell)

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Discussion Questions

How can the Center support data literacy at Bucknell?
What is data literacy to you?
How do you see generative AI changing or impacting data literacy?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Data literacy


It is not the same as mathematical literacy.



So, regardless of your math background, you can develop excellent data skills!

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Terms, Terms, Terms





AI = artificial intelligence

Models that try to predict outcomes.

GenAI = AI models that produce text, images, and videos in response to prompts.
LLMs = large language models

Can produce text that is very similar to human written text.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
section: How are LLMs so good at producing human-like text?
text:
How are LLMs so good at producing human-like text?




Use neural networks, a very flexible type of AI model.






Built on very, very large datasets.



Result: A tool that takes virtually all the data on the internet and predicts what it thinks you want to say.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Prompt Engineering

Prompt: The input you give the LLM to get a response.
Spend time figuring out the problem you are trying to solve.
Clean prompts tend to contain:

A task
A format
A voice
Context

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Example






Identify the task, format, voice, and any context.
What do you think?

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Iterate!






Better prompts yield better outcomes.
Need to practice and refine our prompts to achieve better outcomes from GenAI.
Regardless of how good your prompt is, make sure to always verify the accuracy of the outcome!

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Beware
LLMs give plausible results and rarely admit doubt or lack of knowledge.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Dealing with AI Hallucinations

AI isn‚Äôt much of a time saver if we need to verify all of its claims.
Verification goes much faster if you already have domain knowledge and have developed your critical thinking skills.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
AI and the Classroom



‚ÄúAI promises compelling benefits‚Äîsuch as saving time in busy lives and helping your work to appear more creative or clever‚Äîbut there are many important but invisible tradeoffs in using it, especially in the classroom. Therefore, at least in school, there‚Äôs good reason not to use or rely on AI/LLMs while you‚Äôre still learning new skills and growing as a person, even if it‚Äôs ok to use it in future jobs where producing work is more important than learning.‚Äù ‚Äì Patrick Lin, Philosophy Professor at Cal Poly






Make sure you are having conversations with your professors about what is and is not appropriate use of GenAI in your classes.

Policies will vary from class to class.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Ethical Risks

When you do use GenAI, make sure to credit GenAI contributions in your work through appropriate citations.
You should evaluate the relevance, usefulness, and accuracy of all GenAI outputs.




Investigate the potential harms of GenAI.

On the labor market.
On society.
On the environment.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text:
Ethical Risks



Examine the privacy and data security risks of GenAI.

No confidentiality between you and most AI tools.

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
section: Developing your Data & AI Literacy at Bucknell
text:
Developing your Data & AI Literacy at Bucknell

About developing reasoning

Not just learning definitions and formulae
Not just memorizing arbitrary rules (p-value \(<\) 0.05, sample size \(>\) 30)
Not just accepting any output an AI tool gives you

Requires judgment that takes time to develop

Lots of great classes at Bucknell to start practicing:

MATH 216: Statistics I
DATA 100: Introduction to Data Science (will be offered for the first time this spring)

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text: Opportunities Outside the Classroom

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
section: First Workshop of the Academic Year:  Designing Data Visualizations
text:
First Workshop of the Academic Year:  Designing Data Visualizations
Tuesday, September 9, 2025 4:30-6:00pm, Taylor 210



Want to make your data visualizations stand out? No matter what tool you use, your chart, color, and text choices will have a huge impact on how people interpret your results. This workshop will cover design best practices useful for any platform, so no experience with data visualization tools is required.

üçï and üç™ provided!

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
text: Opportunities Outside the Classroom

title: Dominguez Center for Data Science
section: AI Talk: Data Science in the Age of AI: AI is the Engine & You are the Engineer
text:
AI Talk: Data Science in the Age of AI: AI is the Engine & You are the Engineer
Thursday, November 6th noon - 12:50pm, Taylor 208, Food provided



Generative AI tools are a game-changer for complex data science projects. They can accelerate a project from 0 to 80% complete in a remarkably short amount of time, but the final 20% still demands the skills of a human data scientist to create a robust, nuanced, and context-specific solution.


In this talk, I will walk through several projects I have completed with the help of large language models. With each project, I will show you how to construct tasks for AI and which components require human expertise. My goal is to help you think through the role of the human in data science work and the AI skills you should be developing while you are here at Bucknell and how these skills will prepare you to adapt and stay ahead in the rapidly evolving world after you leave Bucknell.



Guest Speaker: Chester Ismay

text:
